summary: Email correspondence between a federal prosecutor and defense attorney Sigrid McCawley regarding Ghislaine Maxwell's third bail motion. The prosecutor informs McCawley of the motion and notes the government may reference previous victim statements, while acknowledging her client's right to be heard under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA).

persons.name: Sigrid McCawley
persons.context: Partner at Boies Schiller Flexner LLP, representing a victim in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, corresponding with a federal prosecutor about bail proceedings.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused who has submitted a third motion for bail, referenced as the subject of the legal correspondence.

connections.description: McCawley represents a victim in the case against Maxwell, giving her client rights in the bail proceedings.

events.title: Bail Motion Correspondence
events.description: Email exchange regarding Ghislaine Maxwell's third motion for bail, with the government indicating it may reference previous victim statements and acknowledging victims' rights under the CVRA.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell submitted a third motion for bail as of March 1, 2021.
The government anticipated resolving the bail motion 'on the papers' without a hearing, but would notify if a hearing was scheduled.
The government indicated it would likely reference previous victim statements from earlier bail proceedings in its submission.
The correspondence acknowledges the victim's independent right to be heard in connection with bail under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA).
The email shows ongoing legal proceedings and victim representation in the Maxwell case over a year after her arrest.
